docs.text: nih-box 🗃️ Archive, share, and explore projects and files on Box@NIH This is the home of the command-line tool, bx. Its long-term goals: to enable FAIR 1 scientific research, to archive and share project data, and to create a unified tool that makes using Box easier than ever before! Overview ¶ Welcome to bx! Before getting started, we highly recommend reading through bx's documentation . The ./bx command-line tool is composed several inter-related sub commands to explore and archive data across the NIH's Box storage system. Each of the available sub commands perform different functions: bx ls : List Box directory contents. bx cd : Change Box working directories. bx cp : Copy files and directories to/from Box. bx mkdir : Make a new directory on Box. bx rm : Remove files or directories on Box. bx is a command-line tool that make using Box easier than ever before! It leverages Box's python-sdk to make it easy to manage your Box@NIH account. Users who are familiar with unix-like environments will love its easy to remember set of commands. Before getting started, we highly recommend reading through the usage section of each available sub command. For more information about issues or trouble-shooting a problem, please checkout our FAQ prior to opening an issue on Github . Dependencies ¶ Requires: python>=3.8 At the current moment, the only dependency is python! Please install a version of python greater than or equal to 3.8 . Any missing python requirements can be installed with the requirements.txt . Contribute ¶ This site is a living document, created for and by members like you. bx is maintained by the members of OpenOmics and is improved by continous feedback! We encourage you to contribute new content and make improvements to existing content via pull request to our GitHub repository . References ¶ 1. Wilkinson, M. D., Dumontier, M., Aalbersberg, I. J., Appleton, G., Axton, M., Baak, A., Blomberg, N., Boiten, J. W., da Silva Santos, L. B., Bourne, P. E., Bouwman, J., Brookes, A. J., Clark, T., Crosas, M., Dillo, I., Dumon, O., Edmunds, S., Evelo, C. T., Finkers, R., Gonzalez-Beltran, A., … Mons, B. (2016). The FAIR Guiding Principles for scientific data management and stewardship. Scientific data, 3, 160018. https://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2016.18
docs.title: About

docs.text: Welcome to bx! Before getting started, we highly recommend reading through bx's documentation . The ./bx command-line tool is composed several inter-related sub commands to explore and archive data across the NIH's Box storage system. Each of the available sub commands perform different functions: bx ls : List Box directory contents. bx cd : Change Box working directories. bx cp : Copy files and directories to/from Box. bx mkdir : Make a new directory on Box. bx rm : Remove files or directories on Box. bx is a command-line tool that make using Box easier than ever before! It leverages Box's python-sdk to make it easy to manage your Box@NIH account. Users who are familiar with unix-like environments will love its easy to remember set of commands. Before getting started, we highly recommend reading through the usage section of each available sub command. For more information about issues or trouble-shooting a problem, please checkout our FAQ prior to opening an issue on Github .

docs.text: bx cd ¶ 1. About ¶ The bx executable is composed of several inter-related sub commands. Please see bx -h for all available options. This part of the documentation describes options and concepts for bx cd sub command in more detail. With minimal configuration, the cd sub command allows you to change working directories on Box. This allows for interactive exlporation files and directories on the platform. 2. Synopsis ¶ $ bx cd [-h] The synopsis for each command shows its arguments and their usage. Optional arguments are shown in square brackets. More information coming soon!
docs.title: bx cd

docs.text: bx cp ¶ 1. About ¶ The bx executable is composed of several inter-related sub commands. Please see bx -h for all available options. This part of the documentation describes options and concepts for bx cp sub command in more detail. With minimal configuration, the cp sub command allows you to copy local/remote files and directories to/from Box. This allows you to push and pull files and directories from the platform. 2. Synopsis ¶ $ bx cp [-h] The synopsis for each command shows its arguments and their usage. Optional arguments are shown in square brackets. More information coming soon!
docs.title: bx cp

docs.text: bx ls ¶ 1. About ¶ The bx executable is composed of several inter-related sub commands. Please see bx -h for all available options. This part of the documentation describes options and concepts for bx ls sub command in more detail. With minimal configuration, the ls sub command allows you to list files and directory on Box. This allow you see get more information about files and directories on the platform. 2. Synopsis ¶ $ bx ls [-h] The synopsis for each command shows its arguments and their usage. Optional arguments are shown in square brackets. More information coming soon!

This allows you to delete any un-needed files and directories on the platform. 2. Synopsis ¶ $ bx rm [-h] The synopsis for each command shows its arguments and their usage.
